title: Brent crude drops below $50 threshold, hitting six-month low
text:
13,750.00 +150.00 
Oil prices plummet as Opec pumps more oil in July and markets worry about global oversupply 
Brent crude crashed briefly through the $50 per barrel barrier, marking a new six-month low for the benchmark amid continuing worries that the world is producing too much oil. 
The slump in prices followed new estimates which showed that Organisation of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) had produced around 32m barrels per day of oil in July, 2m barrels higher than the 12-member cartel's target. 
Brent fell to $49.74 after the close in London on fears that a slump in prices since last year has failed to pinch a glut of excess oil which has built up in the global supply chain. 
"Besides record-high Saudi Arabian production, a strikingly high level of production in Iraq is playing its part in this, which this summer has risen to over 4m bpd for the first time," said Commerzbank (Xetra: CBK100 - news ) . 
New (KOSDAQ: 160550.KQ - news ) figures released by Oil and Gas UK also showed that the North Sea this year is likely to see its first increase in production for 15 years despite job losses and operators aggressively cutting back in the area. 
The risks to exports from the Middle East and to non-Opec production are currently being ignored by the market, which is hardly surprising in view of the increasingly negative sentiment on the oil market. The offshore watchdog said that output from the North Sea over the first six months of this year could be 2.5pc higher than the same period last year. 
The UK's main producing area is the type of production which Opec had hoped would be squeezed by lower prices because of the high cost of operating offshore. Operating costs in some of the North Sea's oldest fields are estimated to be in the region of $80 per barrel.

â€œClearly the oil price which has more than halved since this time last year continues to really challenge the industry. However, [the production increase] can indeed be attributed to the effort and investment industry has put into improving the integrity and performance of UKCS assets," said Deirdre Michie, chief executive, Oil & Gas UK, in a statement. 
In March, the Chancellor George Osborne offered some relief to oil and gas operators in the North Sea by cutting taxes on the region. Tax rates on production from older oil and gas fields were cut from 80pc to 75pc, falling to 67.5pc from next year. For newer fields, effective rates were trimmed from 60pc to 50pc. 
Commodities were sold down across the board with copper officially entering a bear market on concerns over stuttering Chinese economy growth. 
"We are confident that the Chinese government and central bank will resort to further fiscal and monetary policy measures in a bid to shore up the economy," said Commerzbank.
